question: You are a code expert. Please use your professional knowledge to generate accurate and professional responses. Make sure the code you generate is executable and functional. Design an HTML-based math game centered around quadratic radical operations and solving linear quadratic equations. Include a scoring system and a time limit system.

checklist.title: Is the core quadratic radical operation functionality fully implemented?
checklist.description: Review whether the code accurately implements a system for quadratic radical operations (simplification, addition, multiplication, etc.). Check if the mathematical logic correctly handles operations like √(a²) = |a|, √(a × b) = √a × √b when a,b ≥ 0. Score 0 if the core math operations are incorrect, 5 if basic operations work but edge cases are unhandled, and 10 if all operations are mathematically sound with proper error handling.

checklist.title: Is the linear quadratic equation solving system properly implemented?
checklist.description: Evaluate whether the code can generate valid linear and quadratic equations for solving, with proper validation of user input and solution verification. Check if the quadratic formula (-b ± √(b² - 4ac))/2a is correctly implemented with discriminant handling. Deduct 5 points if the system only handles specific coefficient cases, 3 points if imaginary solutions aren't properly addressed, and 2 points if rounding errors affect solution validation. The full score is 10 points.

checklist.title: Is the scoring system comprehensive and fair?
checklist.description: Check whether the scoring logic rewards correct answers appropriately with graduated difficulty levels. Verify if the system handles partial credit for multi-step problems, and if score tracking persists across game sessions. Deduct 4 points if scoring doesn't account for problem difficulty, 3 points if there's no visual feedback after scoring events, and 3 points if high scores aren't tracked. The full score is 10 points.

checklist.title: Is the time limit system properly implemented and user-friendly?
checklist.description: Assess whether the timer is accurately implemented with appropriate visual cues as time runs low. Check if the system has pause/resume functionality and handles timeout events gracefully. Deduct 4 points if the timer has synchronization issues, 3 points if there's no warning for low time remaining, and 3 points if time penalties/bonuses aren't incorporated for wrong/right answers. The full score is 10 points.

checklist.title: Is the code robust?
checklist.description: Evaluate whether the code can handle common abnormal situations (such as invalid inputs, division by zero, incorrect equation formats, etc.) and provide friendly error prompts or recovery mechanisms. Code with strong robustness should be able to effectively handle mathematical edge cases (e.g., irrational results, large numbers), giving 10 points. If the robustness is average, give 5 points, and if no exceptions are handled, give 0 points.

checklist.title: Are there any innovative features that are eye-catching?
checklist.description: Check whether the code includes surprise features that enhance the experience (e.g., 1. Visual representation of equations/solutions 2. Progressive difficulty adjustment based on user performance 3. Step-by-step solution explanations). Add 3 points for each practical innovative feature implemented (maximum 10 points).

checklist.title: Are there any redundant features?
checklist.description: Strictly check three types of redundancy: 1. Redundant implementation of similar mathematical functions (e.g., multiple equation-solving algorithms) 2. Function modules unrelated to math learning (e.g., unnecessary animations) 3. Fancy effects that affect performance or distract from the learning experience. Deduct 3 points for each redundancy found, and directly deduct 10 points if the core functions are interfered with by redundant code.

checklist.title: Does the code have engineering quality?
checklist.description: Review modular design (such as separating math logic/view/game state management), unit test coverage for mathematical operations, and clean implementation. Deduct 5 points if global state pollution is found or design patterns are not used; deduct 5 points if the code duplication rate is too high (over 30%); deduct 5 points if mathematical functions aren't properly abstracted. The full score is 10 points.

checklist.title: Does the interface vision meet professional design standards?
checklist.description: Evaluate whether the overall design follows modern design principles: 1) Mathematical notation is clear and properly rendered (e.g., using MathJax/KaTeX) 2) Proper layout spacing for equations and input fields 3) Professional font system with appropriate sizing for mathematical expressions. Deduct 3 points for each hard-to-read equation, 5 points for cluttered mathematical notation, and 5 points for inconsistent mathematical formatting. The full score is 10 points.

checklist.title: Is the dynamic interaction smooth and seamless?
checklist.description: Judge whether the dynamic effects conform to human perception characteristics: 1) Immediate feedback on answer submission ≤ 100ms 2) Smooth transitions between problems 3) Clear visual guidance when entering mathematical expressions. Deduct 5 points for each math operation without feedback, 3 points for laggy equation rendering, and 5 points for confusing input methods for mathematical symbols. The full score is 10 points.
